content: - After the collapse of the Austro-Hungarian empire, Slovenia joins the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes, later renamed Yugoslavia.
- Slovenia is occupied by Nazi Germany and Italy during World War II.
- Slovenia becomes a constituent republic of socialist Yugoslavia.
- First multi-party elections. Milan Kucan becomes president. Overwhelming majority of Slovenes vote for independence in a referendum.
- Slovenia, along with Croatia, declares its independence. The Yugoslav federal army intervenes. Slovene forces defend the country. The EU brokers a ceasefire and the Yugoslav army withdraws.

- The EU and US recognise Slovenia's independence, and it joins the United Nations. First parliamentary and presidential elections in the newly independent country. Milan Kucan re-elected president. Janez Drnovsek becomes prime minister.
- Slovenia signs an association agreement with the EU.
- Slovenia, a member of Nato's Partnership for Peace programme, allows Nato to use its airspace during the bombing of Kosovo and Serbia.
December - Prime Minister Janez Drnovsek wins presidential elections.
EU summit in Copenhagen formally invites Slovenia to join in 2004.
March - Referendum vote backs both EU and Nato membership.
March - Slovenia admitted to Nato.
May - Slovenia is one of 10 new states to join the EU.
October - Centre-right Slovenian Democratic Party tops poll in general elections. Party leader Janez Jansa sets about forming coalition government.
January - Slovenia becomes the first former communist state to adopt the single European currency, the euro.
January - Slovenia becomes the first former communist state to assume the EU presidency.
Maribor: Slovenia's second city was rebuilt after the Second World War
November - Social Democratic leader Borut Pahor becomes prime minister at the head of a centre-left coalition comprising three other parties.
September - PM Borut Pahor's centre-left coalition collapses after losing confidence vote in parliament. It remains in office as a caretaker government.
February - Parliament approves new and mainly centre-right government led by Prime Minister Janez Jansa.
November-December - Thousands of people take part in anti-austerity protests in Ljubljana and Slovenia's second city, Maribor.
December - Centre-left former PM Borut Pahor wins presidential election at run-off vote, defeating incumbent Danilo Turk.
March - The Jansa coalition collapses over disputes about austerity measures and corruption allegations. Liberal opposition leader Alenka Bratusek becomes prime minister.

April - European Commission warns that urgent policy action is needed to tackle the problems of Slovenia's banks. Ratings agency Moody's cuts Slovenia's bonds to "junk" status, increasing likelihood that country will have to ask eurozone partners for bailout.
May - Government unveils package of measures aimed at staving off EU bailout.
November - Coalition government wins a confidence vote linked to the budget of 2014, signalling support for plans to rescue banks without recourse to an international bailout.
August - Miro Cerar becomes prime minister after snap elections in July. His liberal SMC party agrees a coalition with two other centre-left parties.
December - Voters in a referendum reject legislation that would have granted same-sex couples the right to marry.
March - Slovenia says it will refuse transit to most migrants seeking to travel through the Balkan route to northern Europe.

June - An international court of arbitration hands Slovenia a victory in its maritime dispute with Croatia, ruling that it should have direct access to international waters in the Adriatic Sea using a corridor crossing Croatian waters.
June - Snap elections see big wins for the SDS anti-immigration party of veteran former prime minister Janez Jansa, as well as for the relatively new centre-left LMS party.
September - Marjan Sarec of the LMS is sworn in as head of a centre-left minority government, after the SDS fails to form a coalition.
March - Janez Jansa returns as head of a centre-right coalition government after Marjan Sarec fails in a bid to call early elections.
